name: NPR
text: More than two months after Vanessa Guillen was last seen, her remains were identified by Army investigators. https://t.co/9eGMuFqyu5

name: NPR
text:
Working moms now spend 15 more hours than working dads on childcare and housework, a recent survey finds. But fewer work hours is just one way the pandemic could widen the gender wage gap. 

It's also pulling women out of work altogether. https://t.co/sPYOKZWTyU

name: NPR
text:
The highways and roads that shape our cities were often intentionally built at the expense of Black, Latino and other minority Americans.

Here's how that still hurts communities of color today. ⬇️
https://t.co/H6WcKx4Alk

name: NPR
text: The University System of Georgia is holding in-person classes this fall, with no masks required. It's an anomaly among top public universities — and it will put people at risk, professors say. https://t.co/cMy5MQ4yQs

name: NPR
text: At 79, 74 and 87 years old, respectively, these three veteran songwriters prove that it's possible to release poignant and powerful work late in an artist's career. https://t.co/XHhnfOACvv

name: NPR
text:
A new ordinance in Somerville, Mass., is believed to be the first in the country that officially recognizes multiple-partner relationships in a municipality. @wgbhnews 
https://t.co/8rzPlz3yuU

name: NPR
text:
After a two-month delay due to the coronavirus, HAIM is finally shraing their third record, Women in Music Pt. III — or WIMPIII. 

NPR spoke to the sisters about some of the darker challenges they explore on it. https://t.co/XUXsWITB83

name: NPR
text:
Review: Horror may not be readers' first choice in times like this, but Emma J. Gibbons' new collection of short stories — influenced by both punk rock and classic literature — is full of great characters and genuine scares.
https://t.co/ee4QkTWxHG

name: NPR
text: On this week's episode of https://t.co/T82m3wDccs, we look at why Afro-Latinx folks often get left out of national discussions about Blackness and, in particular, the Black Lives Matter movement. https://t.co/DrvR0CEF86

name: NPR
text:
Just under 100 years ago, well under 1% of NFL players were African American. That figure now stands at approximately 70%. 

The path to that growth begins, in part, with Fritz Pollard. @OnlyAGameNPR 
https://t.co/mqlkGMqXOa

name: NPR
text:
Federal prosecutors, under scrutiny for failing to turn over favorable evidence to a defendant, told a judge they didn't act in bad faith — even as emails showed them discussing whether they might try to "bury" a document they were giving to the defense.
https://t.co/3ThHmrxSuD

name: NPR
text:
Analysis: President Trump's emphasis on "culture wars" can be seen as a distraction.

But there are things that, in all likelihood, will shape this presidential election far more than "cancel culture." Here are six, based on public opinion surveys.
 https://t.co/AAJ8XFeMXh

name: NPR
text:
A pre-eminent legal scholar and vocal critic of Chinese leader Xi Jinping was taken from his home early Monday and had documents and his computer seized by police, according to close friends.
https://t.co/sBWvAywiCL

name: NPR
text:
When he developed COVID-19 symptoms in early March, doctors didn't give him a confirmatory swab test because he hadn't traveled to China. 

Because of a loophole in federal rules, that meant his insurer didn't have to cover his emergency room visit.
https://t.co/TutuEMg9ud

name: NPR
text:
Ennio Morricone — the iconic Italian composer who scored "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly" and more than 500 other films — died on Monday in Rome. He was 91.
https://t.co/rSKo4JI0Lr

name: NPR
text:
Critics of Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador say he's making a mistake by visiting Washington — and is helping President Trump politically during an election year.

But López Obrador says: "We are going ... with our heads high."
https://t.co/34k1jH3s3Z

name: NPR
text:
A federal judge has ruled that the Dakota Access Pipeline must be emptied for now, while the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers produces an environmental review.

Members of the Standing Rock Sioux tribe have been fighting against its construction for years.
https://t.co/B7kAD24gjC

name: NPR
text:
Actor Nick Cordero died Sunday of COVID-19 at the age of 41. He's survived by his wife, Amanda Kloots, and their 1-year-old son.

"I have honestly never known a kinder person," says actor Zach Braff. "But Covid doesn't care about the purity of your soul."
https://t.co/g9jh13hCEF
